entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 2 at 8:59AM CST by NWS Little Rock AR
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following river in Arkansas...
Cache River Near Patterson affecting Jackson and Woodruff Counties.
For the Cache River...including Patterson...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Cache River near Patterson.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 8.0 feet, Low swampy timberland along the river begins to flood. At 9.0 feet, Low swampy timberland along the river begins to flood. entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 2 at 8:52AM CST by NWS Little Rock AR
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following river in Arkansas...
White River At Augusta affecting Woodruff and White Counties.
For the Lower White River...including Newport, Augusta, Georgetown, Des Arc, Clarendon...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...White River at Augusta.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 26.0 feet, Farm ground along the river in White and Woodruff counties begin to flood. Seasonal agricultural impacts. At 28.0 feet, Roads in Henry Gray Hurricane Lake Wildlife Management area flooded. Thousands of acres of cultivated land flooded in White and Woodruff counties. entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 2 at 5:43AM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
AVWREV
The following message is transmitted at the request of the U.S. Forest Service Sierra Avalanche Center.
BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WARNING
IMMEDIATE BROADCAST REQUESTED
05:45 PST Sun Feb 02 2025
The Sierra Avalanche Center in Truckee has issued a BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WARNING for the following areas:
NWS Reno NV - NVZ002 (Greater Lake Tahoe)...CAZ072 (Greater Lake Tahoe (CA))
* WHAT...The avalanche danger remains HIGH in the backcountry through early Monday morning. Another period of HIGH danger may occur Monday night into Tuesday.
* WHERE...Central Sierra Nevada Mountains between Yuba Pass (Hwy 49) on the north and Ebbetts Pass (Hwy 4) on the south, including the greater Lake Tahoe area. This does not include ski areas or highways where avalanche mitigation programs exist.
* WHEN...In effect from Sun 05:45 PST to Mon 04:00 PST.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous avalanche conditions exist in the mountains due to intense rain, heavy snow, and strong winds. Widespread avalanche activity is very likely. Avalanches large enough to bury or injure people are expected.
* PRECAUTIONARY / PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...Traveling in, near, or below backcountry avalanche terrain is not recommended.
Consult https://www.sierraavalanchecenter.org/ or www.avalanche.org for more detailed information.
Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside the coverage area of this or any avalanche center.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Greater Lake Tahoe Area

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 2 at 6:39AM MST by NWS Rapid City SD
entry.summary:
Patchy dense fog can be expected this morning, particularly over northeastern Wyoming along and north of Interstate 90 and then in and near the Black Hills where the terrain meets the plains.
Motorists should expect rapidly changing visibility, down to near zero at times. Remember to use your low beam headlights in fog, slow down, and provide plenty of braking distance between yourself and the vehicle in front of you.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Butte; Northern Black Hills; Northern Foothills; Rapid City; Central Black Hills; Sturgis/Piedmont Foothills; Southern Meade Co Plains; Northern Campbell; Western Crook; Wyoming Black Hills; Northeastern Crook

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 2 at 6:21AM MST by NWS Pocatello ID
entry.summary:
AVWPIH
* WHAT...Avalanche warning. The avalanche danger is HIGH. Very dangerous avalanche conditions exist.
* WHERE...The Sawtooth, western Smoky, Smoky, and Soldier Mountains - including the mountains near Atlanta, Stanley, Smiley Creek, Baker Creek, Dollarhide Summit and Fairfield.
* WHEN...From 6 AM MST Sunday until 6 AM MST Monday
* IMPACTS...Heavy snow and strong winds are overloading a very weak snowpack. Natural and human-triggered avalanches large enough to bury people are very likely. Some avalanches will be large enough to snap trees and damage structures.

entry.title: Avalanche Advisory issued February 2 at 6:15AM MST by NWS Salt Lake City UT
entry.summary:
SABSLC
* WHAT...Heavy snowfall and strong winds have caused dangerous avalanche conditions to develop this weekend in the Uinta Mountains.
* WHERE...The Uinta Mountains.
* WHEN...In effect from 6 AM MST this morning through 6 AM MST Monday morning.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous avalanche conditions will develop on many slopes today. People are likely to trigger avalanches by being on or below slopes steeper than 30 degrees. Avalanches could be triggered remotely (from a distance) or from below. For updated avalanche information, go to www.utahavalanchecenter.org. What to do...avoid traveling on or underneath steep north-facing terrain at mid and upper elevations in the backcountry. Carry and know how to use avalanche rescue equipment.

cap:parameter.value: THE FOREST SERVICE UTAH AVALANCHE CENTER IN SALT LAKE CITY HAS ISSUED A SPECIAL AVALANCHE BULLETIN WHICH IS IN EFFECT FROM 6 AM MST SUNDAY TO 6 AM MST MONDAY

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 2 at 6:11AM MST by NWS Pocatello ID
entry.summary:
AVWPIH
* WHAT...Avalanche warning. The avalanche danger is HIGH
* WHERE...For the mountains of northern Utah and southeast Idaho, including the northern Wasatch Range and the Bear River Range.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM MST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Heavy snow, drifting by strong winds, rising temperatures and rain have created very dangerous avalanche conditions at all elevations in the backcountry. Today, you should stay off of and out from under slopes steeper than 30 degrees because dangerous human-triggered and natural avalanches are likely. People should avoid all travel in avalanche terrain and stay well clear of avalanche runouts.

cap:parameter.value: The Forest Service Utah Avalanche Center in Salt Lake City has CONTINUED an AVALANCHE WARNING which is in effect until 6 AM MST Monday

entry.title: Winter Storm Watch issued February 2 at 4:54AM PST until February 5 at 10:00AM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Greater Lake Tahoe area, as well as Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra counties, heavy snow. Snow accumulations of 1 to 3 feet above 7000 feet and 1 to 6 inches below 7000 feet. Winds gusting as high as 90 mph along the highest peaks and 50 mph in lower valleys. For Mono County, heavy snow. Snow accumulations of 2 to 4 feet above 8000 feet and up to 5 inches below 8000 feet. Winds gusting as high as 100 mph along the Sierra Crest.
* WHERE...Greater Lake Tahoe Area, Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties, and Mono County.
* WHEN...From Monday afternoon through Wednesday morning.
* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous. Travel could be very difficult to impossible. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday evening and Tuesday morning commutes. Strong winds could cause damage to trees and power lines.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Mono; Greater Lake Tahoe Area

cap:parameter.value: WINTER STORM WATCH NOW IN EFFECT FROM MONDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH WEDNESDAY MORNING

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 2 at 5:49AM MST by NWS Salt Lake City UT
entry.summary:
AVWSLC
* WHAT...The avalanche danger for the warning area is HIGH at all elevations.
* WHERE...For the mountains of northern Utah and southeast Idaho, including the northern Wasatch Range and the Bear River Range.
* WHEN...Until 6 AM MST Monday. Very dangerous avalanche conditions are expected to continue through the weekend and early next week.
* IMPACTS...Heavy snow, drifting by strong winds, rising temperatures, and rain at lower elevations have created very dangerous avalanche conditions at all elevations in the backcountry. Dangerous human-triggered and natural avalanches are likely. People should avoid all travel in avalanche terrain and stay well clear of avalanche runouts. Today, you should stay off of and out from under sloped steeper than 30 degrees.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 2 at 2:49AM PST until February 3 at 10:00PM PST by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
...LIGHT WEEKEND SNOW, LOW ELEVATION SNOW POTENTIAL EARLY NEXT WEEK...
.Light snow showers will continue through the weekend, but high snow levels generally above 4000 feet will limit impacts to only the highest mountains of Trinity County. A cold front Monday will bring a second pulse of snow but also quickly drop snow levels. Snow levels will most likely drop as low as 2000 feet by early Tuesday, especially for the northern half of the area. Heavy snow should be expected in sporadic pulses along highway passes through the week.
* WHAT...For the Winter Weather Advisory above 2500 feet, wet snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 8 inches on high peaks. For the Winter Storm Watch for elevations above 1500 feet, heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations between 4 and 10 inches along highway passes.
* WHERE...Northern Humboldt Interior.
* WHEN...For the Winter Weather Advisory, from 10 PM this evening to 10 PM PST Monday. For the Winter Storm Watch, from Monday evening through late Tuesday night.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow levels will continue to fall through the week, with snow as low as 1000 feet by Wednesday. Sporadic snow showers will continue through the week.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued February 2 at 1:34AM PST until February 2 at 10:00PM PST by NWS Sacramento CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...A portion of northern California, including the following areas, Carquinez Strait and Delta, Central Sacramento Valley, Motherlode, Mountains Southwestern Shasta County to Western Colusa County, Northeast Foothills/Sacramento Valley, Northern Sacramento Valley, Northern San Joaquin Valley, Shasta Lake Area / Northern Shasta County, Southern Sacramento Valley, West Slope Northern Sierra Nevada and Western Plumas County/Lassen Park.
* WHEN...Through this evening.

Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. There is the potential for mud and rock slides in the foothills and mountains.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Periods of moderate to heavy rainfall are expected over the next 18 hours with totals from 1 inch in the Valley, 1 to 4 inches in the foothills, and 2 to 5 inches in the mountains below 6500 feet. Heaviest rain period of rain will be through this afternoon mainly over the northern Sierra, northeast foothills and Northern Sacramento Valley. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

...A WINTER STORM HITS SOUTHERN OREGON AND NORTHERN CALIFORNIA...
.An atmospheric river and stationary front will bring impactful winter weather to the region Sunday through Monday with the most significant impacts Monday morning. The snowfall accumulation will be unusually high east of the Cascades. Travel impacts are likely, especially east of the Cascades and over Siskiyou Summit through this event. Snow will continue to accumulate into Tuesday, although the locations, intensity and elevations will change.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 2 at 1:52AM MST until February 3 at 8:00AM MST by NWS Missoula MT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Winter Weather Advisory, snow expected. Likelihood of minor to moderate impacts from around 1 to 3 inches of snow is 60 percent, and 3 to 6 inches of snow is less than 10 percent. For the Winter Storm Watch, heavy snow possible. Chance of moderate to major impacts from snow is at least 50 percent. Total snow accumulations between 3 and 10 inches possible. Winds could gust as high as 35 mph causing blowing and drifting of snow.
* WHERE...Essex, Bad Rock Canyon, Highway 83 Bigfork to Swan Lake, Polebridge, and Marias Pass.
* WHEN...For the Winter Weather Advisory, from 11 AM this morning to 8 AM MST Monday. For the Winter Storm Watch, from late Monday night through Wednesday morning.

Closures and disruptions to infrastructure may occur. For MAJOR impacts from snow, expect considerable disruptions to normal activities. Dangerous or impossible traveling conditions. Avoid travel in the impacted areas if possible. Widespread closures and disruptions to infrastructure may occur. The hazardous conditions could impact the Monday morning and evening commutes, especially over higher passes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The Arctic front Sunday will bring gusty winds up to 30 mph combined with rapidly dropping temperatures. Lowered visibility and icy roads could make travel difficult.

entry.title: Cold Weather Advisory issued February 2 at 1:45AM MST until February 4 at 11:00AM MST by NWS Great Falls MT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Very cold wind chills as low as 30 below zero expected.
* WHERE...A portion of north central Montana.
* WHEN...From 5 PM this afternoon to 11 AM MST Tuesday.
* IMPACTS...Hazardous wind chills as low as 30 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A cold airmass will deepen across the north-central Montana plains through early this week with widespread subzero temperatures developing tonight and continuing through Tuesday night. Overnight temperatures will range from 10 below zero to as low as around 20 below zero during this period. Northerly winds will bring periods of wind chill as low as 20 below to 30 below zero, especially tonight and again Monday night.

SABOTX
* WHAT...Significant new snow and strong winds, a variable and weak snowpack, and a busy weekend in the backcountry could combine for uniquely dangerous avalanche conditions.

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 1 at 4:48PM MST by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
AVWBOU
THE FOLLOWING MESSAGE IS TRANSMITTED AT THE REQUEST OF THE COLORADO AVALANCHE INFORMATION CENTER.
...AVALANCHE WARNING IN EFFECT 5 PM SATURDAY UNTIL 5 PM SUNDAY...
*WHAT...Heavy snow and strong winds will result in very dangerous avalanche conditions and a HIGH (Level 4 of 5) avalanche danger on Sunday.
*WHERE...Elkhead and Park Mountains.
*WHEN... Expect very dangerous avalanche conditions to develop on Saturday night and last through Sunday daytime.
*IMPACTS...Large and dangerous avalanches will be very easy to trigger in many places. Avalanches will run naturally.
*PRECAUTION/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS... Travel in backcountry avalanche terrain is not recommended on Sunday. Avoid travel on and under slopes steeper than about 30 degrees. You can find more detailed information at colorado.gov/avalanche

entry.title: Flood Watch issued February 1 at 2:05PM PST until February 4 at 4:00PM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of California, including the following areas, Greater Lake Tahoe Area and Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties and western Nevada, including the following area, Greater Lake Tahoe Area.
* WHEN...Through Tuesday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff will result in rapid rises and potential flooding of rivers, creeks and streams, as well as poor drainage and urban areas. Minor to moderate mainstem river flooding is currently forecast along the Pit river below Canby, the Susan River at Susanville, and Middle Fork of the Feather rivers near Portola. Other rivers in the area are forecast to rise significantly, but not currently expected to exceed flood stages. Recent burn areas including the Davis in Washoe County, the Bear in Sierra County, and the Mill in Plumas County, are prone to increased runoff and transport of sediment. Sediment from burns may plug drainages and result in flooding in unexpected areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Greater Lake Tahoe Area

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued February 1 at 11:09AM PST by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The South Coast AQMD has updated a mandatory wood-burning ban for residents in the South Coast Air Basin. The No-Burn rule bans burning wood, pellets, and manufactured fire logs in any indoor or outdoor wood-burning device.
* WHERE...The South Coast Air Basin, which includes Orange County and non-desert portions of Los Angeles, Riverside, and San Bernardino counties. No-Burn Day alerts do not apply to areas above 3,000 feet in elevation, the Coachella Valley, or the High Desert. Homes that rely on wood as a sole source of heat, low-income households and those without natural gas service also are exempt from the requirement.
* WHEN...all of Saturday and Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Particles in smoke can get deep into the lungs and cause health problems (including asthma attacks), increases in emergency room visits, and hospitalizations. No-Burn Days are needed to protect public health when fine particle pollution levels are expected to be high anywhere in the South Coast Air Basin. No-Burn Days are based on fine particle pollution levels that are forecasted for an entire 24-hour period, which may not be reflected in real- time air quality maps.

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT: MANDATORY WOOD-BURNING BAN IN EFFECT

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued February 1 at 10:53AM PST by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The South Coast AQMD has updated a mandatory wood-burning ban for residents in the South Coast Air Basin. The No-Burn rule bans burning wood, pellets, and manufactured fire logs in any indoor or outdoor wood-burning device.
* WHERE...The South Coast Air Basin, which includes Orange County and non-desert portions of Los Angeles, Riverside, and San Bernardino counties. No-Burn Day alerts do not apply to areas above 3,000 feet in elevation, the Coachella Valley, or the High Desert. Homes that rely on wood as a sole source of heat, low-income households and those without natural gas service also are exempt from the requirement.
* WHEN...all of Saturday and Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Particles in smoke can get deep into the lungs and cause health problems (including asthma attacks), increases in emergency room visits, and hospitalizations. No-Burn Days are needed to protect public health when fine particle pollution levels are expected to be high anywhere in the South Coast Air Basin. No-Burn Days are based on fine particle pollution levels that are forecasted for an entire 24-hour period, which may not be reflected in real- time air quality maps.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued February 1 at 12:32PM EST until February 2 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Morristown TN
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Morristown has issued a Flood Advisory for the following rivers in Tennessee...
Powell River Near Arthur TN affecting Claiborne and Union Counties.
For the Powell River...including Jonesville VA, Arthur TN...elevated river levels are forecast.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...Powell River near Arthur TN.
* WHEN...From this afternoon to tomorrow evening.
* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Action stage. At 17.0 feet, Minor flooding begins.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:15 PM EST Saturday the stage was 12.8 feet. - Bankfull stage is 17.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 16.0 feet just after midnight tonight. - Action stage is 15.0 feet. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM THIS AFTERNOON TO TOMORROW EVENING

entry.title: Avalanche Advisory issued January 31 at 5:12PM PST by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
SABPQR
* WHAT...Significant new snow and strong winds, a variable and weak snowpack, and a busy weekend in the backcountry could combine for uniquely dangerous avalanche conditions.
* WHERE...The Washington Cascades from the Canadian Border to the Columbia River, Mt Hood, and the Olympic Mountains.
* WHEN...In effect from Fri 18:00 PST to Sun 18:00 PST.
* IMPACTS...Avalanches large enough to bury, injure or kill a person may be easy to trigger on a variety of slopes. Avalanches may break widely across the slope.

entry.title: Avalanche Advisory issued January 30 at 6:18PM PST by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
SABPQR
* WHAT...A SIGNIFICANT WINTER STORM, A VARIABLE AND WEAK SNOWPACK, AND A BUSY WEEKEND COULD COMBINE FOR UNIQUELY DANGEROUS AVALANCHE CONDITIONS. AVALANCHES MAY TRIGGER EASILY AND COULD BREAK WIDELY.
* WHERE...THE WASHINGTON CASCADES FROM THE CANADIAN BORDER TO THE COLUMBIA RIVER, MT HOOD, AND THE OLYMPIC MOUNTAINS.
* WHEN...IN EFFECT FROM THU 18:00 PST TO SUN 18:00 PST.
* IMPACTS...A PROLONGED DRY PERIOD IN JANUARY CREATED A HIGHLY VARIABLE AND POTENTIALLY WEAK SNOWPACK. ACTIVE WEATHER INCLUDING SIGNIFICANT SNOWFALL AND WINDS COULD MAKE THESE LAYERS UNSTABLE. HUMANS MAY EASILY TRIGGER AVALANCHES LARGE ENOUGH TO BURY OR INJURE A PERSON.
